titleStmt.title: Diary of S. Pearl Robinson [manuscript], 1865 January to June.
diary of s. pearl, 1865 january to june

projectDesc.p: Prepared for the University of Virginia Library by Digital Curation Services staff and volunteer Mary Roy Dawson Edwards, Transcriber. March 2007.

div1.head:
Diary of S. Pearl Robinson[manuscript]
1865 January to June.

div3.head: Entry 1
div3.p: S. Pearl Robinson Co. D 10 Reg Vt
Cold and Clear. I was on Picket.
Warm growing Came off picket
mild and cloudy snowing in the evening.
clear and cold
in Camp pleasant and Warming
on fatique [-] warm and rained
in quarters
clear and cold, on Camp guard at Fort [-]
warm of ground and went into Camp line or tacked on our left Dress parade in the evening
rained hard during the day
clear and pleasant
pleasant
pleasant
clear & cold. went on picket on reserve Capt. Davis and Crane went home on furlough
cold and chilly relieved from picket dress parade in the evening
very pleasant drill. one hour dress parade
cold on fatigue
quite pleasant inspecting quarters
cloudy dress parade one half hour drill
cold went on picket
cold rained all day came of picket
cloudy
rained boys on picket I was on fatigue
pleasant come of picket
cold. Batteryline drill two hours
cold
cold as the Devil
cold and windy
cold went on picket
warm came of picket. Brig dress parade
Very pleasant company drill in afternoon.
cold company drill in the morning
clear on fatigue at Fort Wadsworth{1}
[-] warm company drill in morning Battallion drill rained and snowed
Clear and plesant Battallion drill one hour dress paraid reten a letter to Leucia
Clear and Cold orders to march but did not go hard fiting on the left this after noon Orders to march at a moment notis
clear and plesant Dress praid
Clear and pleasant going on picket Stormy as the Devil rained all day hard fight on the left at nite
clear but very cold came off picket
Cold and Cloudy
Cold and Cloudy
warm and pleasant
Wind blows hard and very cold
clear and cold Went on picket changed coffee for tobackto With the rebs
cold and cloudy came of picket
cold and rainy all day
Warm and pleasant in Camp all day monthly in specttion
cold and rainy all day on fituege at fort fisher
clear and plesant in Camp all day
clear and plesant all day on pickett
clear and warm came off picket Brigaid Review in the afternoon a letter from home
Clear and plesant on guard
Clear and pleasant came off guard Divison Review at half past two
Warm and rainy all day on fitueg
Warm and Cloudy Signed the pay rolls this after non
Cloudy and rainy all day on fitueg at fort fisher paid off for four monts sent twenty dollars home by G. E. Davis 26. cloudy and Winday
Clear and plesant on fitueg all day at fort fisher
Rainy all day on picket
Warm and Cloudy came off picket dress praid
Warm and Cloudy rainy on fitueg at fort fisher
Warm and Cloudy went over to the old Brigaid
Warm and Cloudy on picket
Clear and plesant came of picket
Clear and plesant on fitueg at fort Fisher
Clear and plesant in camp all day
Warm and Cloudy rained in the after noon
Cloudy in the morning rained in the after noon on Picket
Clear and Warm came off Picket
Clear and Plesant one man shot in our Divison to day one ours drill in the after noon
Clear and Plesant on picket
Clear and Plesant Came off Picket on fitueg in the after noon had a letter from Mary
Warm and plesant on camp Guard writin a letter to Charley monthily in Spection orders to move at a moment notis
Warm and Cloudy in Camp all day
Wind blue like hell all day and rained in the evening on picket
Clear and pleasant Came off picket
Clear and plesant in camp all day
Clear and plesant on picket five rebs came in last nite on the next post to me
Clear and plesant came off picket
Warm and winday in the morning rained in the after noon and evning
Clear and pleasant on fitueg in the Woods
Clear but very Winday in the morning Winday all day
Clear and [-] Cold Went on picket
heavy attack on the write and soon the whole length of the line carred the first line of the Rebs Works With a very little loss a letter from home
Clear and cold Just came off picket evry thing all quiet
Clear and cold Just came off picket Clear and Warm going on picket to nite
Clear and plesant came off picket
Clear and plesant broke Camp in the four noon and Went down on the left in the works heavy canena d ing on the left
rainy all day laying in the Works hard fiting on the left cared two lines of the rebels works
clear and pleasant Went in the camp at three O clock the 24 Corps is a going to charge the works to nite if they get repulced we will hafto go and give it a try sent a letter home to nite
Clear and plesant in Camp inspection at ten it is all quiet on the lines
Clear and plesant We {2} charged the rebels works at four P.M. and cared them took a lot of prisners Charles Sawyer wounded and [-]
started on a march to foll the rebs Richmon is ours this morning at 8 P.M. and Petersburg{3}
Cloudy and Warm marched about 5 miles Drew three day rations Started marching about 8 miles halting at 9 Oclock for the Night
Started marching about marching about 5 miles halting & Drew 3 days rations Started marching about 12 miles halting about 8 Oclock for the night
Started at 6 6 Oclock A.M. marching about 18 miles forming line of Battle and Charging the enemy Driving them in confusion 9000 prisoners 16 pieces Arty & G Ewell Captured{4}

Started marching about 3 miles halting for Dinner Started marching 5 miles halting near Farmingstown also crossing the Appomattux River rained Some Gen Custer and Staff passed
bearing 30 Rebel battle flags

pleasant, broke Camp at 8 O clock halted two hours in forenoon to draw Rations, drew three days Orders they are to last six, Camped at 9 O clock P.M. having marched twelve miles, no signs of the enemy,
pleasant. left Camp in the morning marched 8 miles Genl. Lee surrendered up his whole forces to Gen Grant they was great rejoicing among the troops on both sides
Cloudy & rainy laid in Camp all day for the first time since started on the Campaign Mail went out for the first time also, order to move at 6 Oclock in the morning, wrete Home
Cloudy and rainy, broke Camp at 6 Oclock A.M. marched back the same road we went, Camped for the night in a piece of Woods 8 miles from Farmville, having marched eighteen miles, roads very muddy
Cloudy and rainy started about 10 A.M. marched to burk station the distons about 12 miles went into Camp Druemasions {6} for four days at night two letters from Charley
Clear and plesant fixed up camp dress praid at night 1 letter from home 1 letter from Lucia
Cloudy and rainy all day in Camp went over to the old Brigaid at nite
Clear and plesant Regimental inspection at 10 A.M. drespraid at 5 P.M.
Clear and plesant in camp all day drespraid at five O Clock
Clear and plesant drespraid at five OClock sent a letter to Charley
Clear and plesant in Camp all day Went over to the old Brigaid at nite
Cloudy and rainy all day Went ou ot a forigen [?] Came in at twelve at nite
Clear and plesant Went on picket in the after noon
pleasant. Regiment relieved from Picket in the evening
pleasant. broke Camp at daylight and moved in the direction of Danvill, marched near the Rail-Road Camped at 6 Oclock for the night
pleasant, broke Camp at 7 A.M. marched in the same direction as yesterday, halted near the Staunton River at night
pleasant, Crossed the River on a Pontoon Bridge in the morning marched in the same direction Crossed the Bannister River{7} halted near it for the night

pleasant, through the Town of Bannister in the morning, "Band playing" &c Stars & Stripes floating from the "Court=House" a very pleasant Country we are passing through now, have passed Several larg Mansions.
pleasant, reached Danville today at 8. O.clock P.M. having been on the march five days and traveled over one hundred Miles.
pleasant, lay out our camp in a piece of woods two miles from the Town. "Official -Despatch," came today of the "Surrender" of Johnson the day spent in pitching our tents and Policing our Camp
pleasant, in the forenoon, cloudy in the afternoon, rained towards night, for the first time since the 15th Inst. Policing our Camp & same as yesterday
pleasant, part of the Regiment on Picket, "Muster-Day". Policing after Muster
warm & pleasant, Regt relieved from Picket. all quiet, nothing new,
pleasant, Mail came for the first time since we got to this place. No-News,
pleasant, obtained a "Pass" to go to the Town, all quiet there bought some Sugar &c,
pleasant in the forenoon Cloudy in the afternoon on picket evry thing all quiet now news the last of the first Divison Went this morning
Clear and pleasant Came of picket
Clear and plesant in camp all day no news to day.
Cloud and rained in the afternoon on fitueg about to ours in the afternoon riten a letter to Father
Clear and plesant in camp all day evry thing all quiet received a letter from home
Cloudy and looks very much like rain the most of the regiment went on picket I went down to Danvill to day
clear and plesant in camp all day riten a letter to Father to day and one to Charley,
Clear and plesant Went over to the fifth Regiment Gerome went into the pineers to day There is know news
Clear and plesant went on fitueg in the afternoon
Clear and plesant inspection at 11 A.M. of every thing Brigaid dress praid at 6 O clock P.M. riten a letter to Margaret [?]
Clear and very Warm air this afternoon Went on picket came off at nite Dryl four days rasions to nite
Clear and plesant broak Camp at 6 A.M. marched to Danvill took the cars at 10 A.M. and arived at Burkstation at 6 P.M. know news
Clear and very Warm arrived at Richmond at 7 A.M. and went into Camp in the afternoon the three rite compinys the rest of the Regiment has not come up
Clear and plesant I went down to Manchester in the afternoon
Cloudy in the morn ing and rained in the afternoon know news to day
Clear and plesant in the Morning showers in the afternoon Dress praid at 6 P.M.
Very warm and plesant all day in Camp
Warm and cloudy Very heavy thunder in the eavning Went down to Manchester ordiers to march at 4 A.M. on guard
Clear and plesant orders to march was counterd manded came of guard
Clear and plesant Started to march at 5 A.M. and past review in Richmond by Geniral Hallock and marched twenty milds from Richmond
Clear and warm as the Devil Started at 6 A.M. from Hanover Courthous halted for the nite at Chester field Station the distance about 11 miles
Rainy all day started marching at 7 A.M. marched about 10 miles and went into camp in the fields
Cloudy and rainy all day laid in Camp days rations know news

div3.head:
May
28.
div3.p: Clear and plesant in camp
Clear and plesant break camp at five A.M. and marched to this Fredhkburg the Distance is about 22 milds marched it in 8 ours went into camp at 1 P.M.
plesant, broke Camp at 7 O,clk passed through the City and crossed the Rappahannock River on a Pontoon Bridge , also crossed Acqruer Creek, camped at 5 O,clk
plesant, broke Camp at 6 O,clk fell out of the Ranks at noon & made Coffee. Colume halted at 1, O,clk for the day.
pleasant, broke Camp at 6 O,clock, crossed "Wolf-Run" "Shoals," halted at noon for Coffee. Camped at Fairfax Station for the night
pleasant, broke Camp at 6 O,clock passed Fairfax Court=House arrived at Baileys Cross Roads at 2 O,clk P.M. where we are to Camp for the present.
pleasant, lay out our Camp &c. very warm & uncomfortable weather now
pleasant, Regimental Inspection in afternoon nothing of importance going on. a good many Visitors from the City here
pleasant, Orders. - Two Dress Parades daily. one at 9 Oclock A.M. & one at Retreat. had both today, some signs of rain this eve, dress Clothing
Cloudy & quite cool. Two "dress -Parades" Orders all Vermont Troops to be Reviewed tomorrow by Gov. Smith. We are to move at 8 .oc
pleasant, moved at 8, Oclock A.M. in "light marching orders" to Baileys- Cross Roads where we were reviewed by Gov. Smith, The Old Vermont Brigade 1st Vt Cavelry & 8th Infantry there
pleasant, moved at 4 O,clock in "light=marching Order" to Washington, Reviewed & back to Camp at 2,Ock. P.M. a very hot day. Ambulances filled with Soldiers who were played-out
pleasant, a very quiet day Regimental Dress-Parade at 6 Oclock P.M.
pleasant in forenoon, rainy in afternoon Washed my clothes &c, nothing new in Camp.
pleasant in Camp all day
pleasant a very quiet day Regimental Dress Parade at 6 O clock P.M.
Cloudy in the fournoon and reigned in the after noon nothing new
pleasant all day, no news,
rained all night, cloudy & cool today, Sanitary-Commision gave us many articles of clothing today,
cloudy in forenoon, pleasant in afternoon, Van Deusen & Dimmick of this Company enlisted in the Regular Service today
pleasant, Obrien enlisted today no news
pleasant, Company Inspection this afternoon
plesant, 14th Jersey Regiment of the Brigade mustered out this afternoon. a light-shower this evening
pleasant in forenoon a very heavy Thunder Shower this afternoon
pleasant, the "muster out" - "Rools" of the Regiment, examined by the "mustering out" Officer today{9}
started for the woods time commenced this morning !!!!!!1/3!!*111111*111111* !!!!!!*111111*

div3.head:
August
10.{10}
div3.p: Commenced work this 5 day of April 1866 [This line not legible.] Received 6 ½ Dollars recived 1 Dollar recived 5 Dollars recived 1 Dollar
3.75 paid recived 15 Dollars recived 4 Dollars recived 6.00 Dollars recived 1.00 Dollar recived pay 1.00 recived 5.00 Dollars
recived Dollars

div3.head:
August
16.
div3.p: 1 day lost half day lost 6 days lost

Roberts 5
Roberts
Mibills 2
Mibills 2
Mibills 1

div3.head: November{12}
div3.p: 16. 1 Mors
2 Mors 2
Colby ½ lb of tobaco .50 Crossed 2 lb of baken To Wit 5 lb of flour .50

div3.head: Cash Account - January
div3.p: April 21 Borod [ 10 Dollars of John Dolan

div3.head: n.d.
div3.p:
Mours 10 loads of Wood
5 loads of Wood

div1.head: Notes
div1.p: [Transcription Notes: Mary Jo Kline's transcription style as suggested in her A Guide to Documentary Editing, Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins Press, 1987, has been followed for S. Pearl Robinson's Diary. The diary measures 3" X 4 ½". The cover is black leather. The paper is lined. The dates are pre-printed. Every attempt has been made to transcribe this document literally. Spelling and punctuation are reproduced as found. Robinson often spells as he hears a word when he is not sure of the correct spelling. For example, "fatigue" is spelled "fitueg". Since punctuation and capitalization are seldom used by the author, three spaces are inserted to denote the end of one thought and the beginning of another. When words are inserted above the line by the author, the symbol "^" is used with the inserted words enclosed is apostrophes, such as ^ 'this'. Comments by the transcriber are placed within square brackets. To denote a word that cannot be discerned, [-] is used. If a word or a proper name is unclear, a question mark is used, thus [?].

note.p: [Fort Wadsworth is at East Verrazano Narrows, near Staten Island, N. Y.]
[The handwriting on this page is somewhat different.]
[General Ewell captured at Sayler's Creek, Va.]
[See transcription notes at the end of this transcription.]
[Banister River is in Pittsylvania Co., Va.]
[There are no further entries until 1867 when he writes in pencil on the July 31st page.]
[On the August 10-11-12 pages, he writes in pencil.]
[August 13, 14, & 15 contain notations of dollar amounts but no mention of for what.]
[At the end of the diary are the following notations:]
